parts:
Unpack and analysize the latest OpenAI announcement

---

AI progress and recommendations
AI is unlocking new knowledge and capabilities. Our responsibility is to guide that power toward broad, lasting benefit.


Listen to article
7:41
Share
When the popular conception of the Turing test went whooshing by, many of us thought it was a little strange how much daily life just kept going. This was a milestone people had talked about for decades. It felt impossibly out of reach, then all of a sudden it felt close, then all of a sudden we were on the other side. We got some great new products and not much about the world changed, even though computers can now converse and think about hard problems.

Most of the world still thinks about AI as chatbots and better search, but today, we have systems that can outperform the smartest humans at some of our most challenging intellectual competitions. Although AI systems are still spikey and face serious weaknesses, systems that can solve such hard problems seem more like 80% of the way to an AI researcher than 20% of the way. The gap between how most people are using AI and what AI is presently capable of is immense.

AI systems that can discover new knowledge—either autonomously, or by making people more effective—are likely to have a significant impact on the world.

In just a few years, AI has gone from only being able to do tasks (in the realm of software engineering specifically) that a person can do in a few seconds to tasks that take a person more than an hour. We expect to have systems that can do tasks that take a person days or weeks soon; we do not know how to think about systems that can do tasks that would take a person centuries.

At the same time, the cost per unit of a given level of intelligence has fallen steeply; 40x per year is a reasonable estimate over the last few years! 

In 2026, we expect AI to be capable of making very small discoveries. In 2028 and beyond, we are pretty confident we will have systems that can make more significant discoveries (though we could of course be wrong, this is what our research progress appears to indicate).

We’ve long felt that AI progress plays out in surprising ways, and that society finds ways to co-evolve with the technology. Although we expect rapid and significant progress in AI capabilities in the next few years, we expect that day-to-day life will still feel surprisingly constant; the way we live has a lot of inertia even with much better tools.

In particular, we expect the future to provide new and hopefully better ways to live a fulfilling life, and for more people to experience such a life than do today. It is true that work will be different, the economic transition may be very difficult in some ways, and it is even possible that the fundamental socioeconomic contract will have to change. But in a world of widely-distributed abundance, people’s lives can be much better than they are today.

AI systems will help people understand their health, accelerate progress in fields like materials science, drug development, and climate modeling, and expand access to personalized education for students around the world. Demonstrating these kinds of tangible benefits helps build a shared vision of a world where AI can make life better, not just more efficient.

OpenAI is deeply committed to safety⁠, which we think of as the practice of enabling AI’s positive impacts by mitigating the negative ones. Although the potential upsides are enormous, we treat the risks of superintelligent systems as potentially catastrophic and believe that empirically⁠ studying⁠ safety⁠ and alignment⁠ can help global decisions, like whether the whole field should slow development to more carefully study these systems as we get closer to systems capable of recursive self-improvement. Obviously, no one should deploy superintelligent systems without being able to robustly align and control them, and this requires more technical work. 

Here are several things we think could help with achieving a positive future with AI:

Shared standards and insights from the frontier labs. 
We think that frontier labs should agree on shared safety principles and to share safety research⁠, learnings about new risks, mechanisms to reduce race dynamics, and more. We can imagine ideas like frontier labs agreeing to certain standards around AI control evaluations being quite helpful.

Society went through a similar process to establish building codes and fire standards, which have saved countless lives.

An approach to public oversight and accountability commensurate with capabilities, and that promotes positive impacts from AI and mitigates the negative ones. 
There are two schools of thought about AI. One is that AI is like “normal technology,” in that it will progress like other technological revolutions in the past, from the printing press to the internet. Things will play out in ways that give people and society a chance to adapt, and conventional tools of public policy should work. We will need to prioritize ideas like promoting innovation, protecting the privacy of conversations with AI and defending against misuse of powerful systems by bad actors by partnering with the federal government.

We believe AI at around today’s capability levels is roughly here, and should diffuse everywhere, which means most developers and open-source models, and almost all deployments of today’s technology, should have minimal additional regulatory burdens relative to what already exists. It certainly should not have to face a 50-state patchwork

The other one is where superintelligence develops and diffuses in ways and at a speed humanity has not seen before. Here, we should do most of the things above, but we also will need to be more innovative. If the premise is that something like this will be difficult for society to adapt to in the “normal way,” we should also not expect typical regulation to be able to do much either. In this case, we will probably need to work closely with the executive branch and related agencies of multiple countries (such as the various safety institutes) to coordinate well, particularly around areas such as mitigating AI applications to bioterrorism (and using AI to detect and prevent bioterrorism) and the implications of self-improving AI.

The high-order bit should be accountability to public institutions, but how we get there might have to differ from the past.

Building an AI resilience ecosystem. 
In either scenario, building out an AI resilience ecosystem will be essential. When the internet emerged, we didn’t protect it with a single policy or company—we built an entire field of cybersecurity: software, encryption protocols, standards, monitoring systems, emergency response teams etc. That ecosystem didn’t eliminate risk, but it reduced it to a level society could live with, enabling people to trust digital infrastructure enough to build their lives and economies on it. We will need something analogous for AI, and there is a powerful role for national governments to play in promoting industrial policy to encourage this.

Ongoing reporting and measurement from the frontier labs and governments on the impacts of AI. 
Understanding how AI is concretely impacting the world makes it easier to steer this technology towards positive impact. Prediction is hard: for example, the impact of AI on jobs has been hard to anticipate, in part because today’s AIs strengths and weaknesses are very different from those of humans. Measuring what’s happening in practice is likely to be very informative.

Building for individual empowerment. 
We believe that adults should be able to use AI on their own terms, within broad bounds defined by society. We expect access to advanced AI to be a foundational utility in the coming years—on par with electricity, clean water, or food. Ultimately, we think society should support making these tools widely available and that the north star should be helping empower people to achieve their goals.

thoughts.content: It looks like I'll focus on the blog's key themes: AI discovery timelines (2026 small, 2028 significant changes), cost curve, and Turing test advancements. I'll also touch on regulation for current AI vs. superintelligence, shared safety standards, and AI resilience. I'll cite relevant parts of the blog with key quotes, sticking to the word count limits.

entries.title: Sam Altman says the cost of using AI will drop by 10 times every year
entries.snippet: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, stated that the cost of AI usage decreases by tenfold every year, which will result in increased usage. In his blog post, he compared this drop in cost to Moore's law, highlighting the significant reduction in AI costs from GPT-4 in early 2023 to GPT-4o in mid-2024. Altman also noted that AI model intelligence correlates with the resources used for development and that continued investment will likely lead to super-exponential growth in AI intelligence. He predicted that this trend would significantly impact society, reducing the costs of many goods while increasing the prices of luxury items and limited resources like land. His comments follow a recent sell-off in AI-linked stocks due to DeepSeek's cheaper high-performance models. Despite this, major tech companies are increasing their AI investments, with collective expenditures set to surpass $320 billion. Additionally, Altman referenced the $500 billion Stargate AI infrastructure project announced by President Donald Trump, involving OpenAI, SoftBank, Oracle, and MGX.

entries.title: Sam Altman says OpenAI will own 'well over 1 million GPUs' by the end of the year - ChatGPT maker continues to expand rapidly
entries.snippet:
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman announced that the company is set to surpass 1 million GPUs online by the end of 2025, vastly exceeding the 200,000 used by competitors like xAI. This milestone underlines OpenAI's dominance in AI compute, and Altman has even hinted at future goals 100 times larger. Though jokingly framed, his ambition to reach 100 million GPUs—costing $3 trillion at current rates—is part of a broad strategy to scale toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). This exponential growth has been driven in part by shortages of AI hardware like Nvidia's H100 chips, which previously delayed model rollouts.

OpenAI has aggressively expanded its infrastructure, including a Texas data center consuming 300 MW and expected to hit 1 GW by mid-2026. Partnering with Microsoft and Oracle, and exploring alternatives like Google's TPUs, OpenAI is diversifying its computing ecosystem. The rapid growth and massive energy demands are drawing concerns from energy regulators, but Altman remains focused on long-term innovation, possibly including in-house chip development. While hitting 100 million GPUs isn't feasible yet, Altman's vision reflects a relentless pursuit of AGI and sets a new benchmark in the AI arms race.

entries.title: OpenAI makes 5-year business plan to meet $1tn spending pledges
entries.snippet:
OpenAI has developed a five-year business strategy to support over $1 trillion in spending commitments aimed at advancing world-class artificial intelligence. To meet these liabilities, the company is diversifying its revenue streams, forming new debt partnerships, and boosting fundraising. Key components include custom AI services for governments and enterprises, monetizing its video AI tool Sora and AI agents, launching consumer hardware alongside designer Jony Ive, and potentially entering online advertising. OpenAI is also exploring new infrastructure funding models and may offer computing resources via its Stargate data center initiative.

The company, with $13 billion in annual recurring revenue—70% from ChatGPT subscriptions—has significant operational losses, such as $8 billion in H1 2025, though revenue doubled year-over-year. Only 5% of ChatGPT's 800 million users currently pay, a figure OpenAI aims to double. Partnerships with Oracle, AMD, and Nvidia include staggered capacity commitments and innovations in chip design. However, questions arise due to the immense future power demands and the circular nature of some funding deals. Despite these challenges, executives remain confident in achieving financial sustainability through rapid growth, cost reductions, and continued investor support.

parts:
Here’s the short version first, then the analysis.

## TL;DR
OpenAI just published a strategy note laying out (i) a near-term capability timeline (small discoveries by ~2026; more significant ones ~2028), (ii) an aggressive cost curve claim (≈40× cheaper “per unit of intelligence” each year recently), and (iii) a policy stance that splits today’s systems (“normal tech,” minimal extra regulation) from future superintelligence (bespoke oversight, state coordination, and “AI resilience” infrastructure). It’s a directional manifesto plus some clear signals about where their research, partnerships, and governance are heading. citeturn1view0

---

## What’s actually new
- **Explicit capability timetable.** “Very small discoveries” by 2026; “more significant discoveries” from 2028. That’s the firmest public dating they’ve put on discovery-grade AI. Treat it as a directional forecast, not a binding roadmap. citeturn1view0  
- **A steep cost-curve claim.** They assert ~**40×/year** reduction in cost for a fixed capability level “over the last few years.” If even partially durable, it underwrites rapid diffusion and more agentic workloads; if it slows, the economics of “AI everywhere” look different. citeturn1view0  
- **Two-lane regulation view.** Today’s models: diffuse widely, avoid a “50-state patchwork,” keep burdens light. Superintelligence: tighter executive-branch coordination across countries and safety-institute style oversight. This is the clearest articulation of their preferred regulatory split. citeturn1view0  
- **“AI resilience ecosystem.”** They want something like cybersecurity’s stack (standards, monitoring, incident response) for AI. That meshes with the **OpenAI Foundation’s** announced $25B initial focus areas (health + AI resilience) after the recapitalization. citeturn1view0turn2view0  
- **Adoption + supply signals around the announcement:**  
  - **1M paying business customers** and rapid growth in enterprise seats (context for “normal tech” lane). citeturn4view0  
  - A **$38B multi-year AWS compute deal**—a notable multi-cloud posture that hedges supply and scale for training/agentic workloads. citeturn3view0

---

## How to read it (and where to be skeptical)

1) **Timelines**  
- The 2026/2028 milestones concern *discovery capability*, not general autonomy. The phrase “we could be wrong” is doing real work; interpret as a *central* scenario rather than a high-confidence forecast. citeturn1view0

2) **40×/year cost fall**  
- This is an aggressive, nonstandard metric. It likely blends model/infra efficiency, utilization gains, and pricing. Expect volatility: supply shocks, energy constraints, and hard limits on latency/quality can interrupt this glidepath. (OpenAI’s own capex/compute posture—e.g., AWS deal—acknowledges scale risk.) citeturn3view0

3) **Two-lane policy**  
- Today’s “light-touch” lane helps open-source and broad deployment; the superintelligence lane tacitly accepts that conventional rulemaking may be too slow. The missing piece is *trigger criteria*: What concrete eval thresholds, operational risk metrics, or incident classes move a model from Lane A → Lane B? (They hint at “AI control evaluations” as a standard, but no specifics yet.) citeturn1view0

4) **AI resilience**  
- The analogy to cybersecurity is apt, but resilience requires *markets + mandates*: shared incident taxonomies, red-team clearinghouses, model/agent SBOMs, audit logs, kill-switch standards, and insurer-backed risk pricing. The Foundation’s remit and funding suggest they’ll try to catalyze this—watch for grants and reference implementations. citeturn2view0

5) **“80% of the way to an AI researcher”**  
- Framing, not a measured claim. On real research benchmarks, performance is spiky; robust autonomy still hinges on verification, tool use, and long-horizon planning. Treat the line as product-strategy rhetoric to push “agentic” use cases, not evidence that human-in-the-loop is obsolete. citeturn1view0

---

## Strategic implications

**For labs & builders**
- Expect **agentic systems** that run longer, chain tools, and tackle week-long tasks. Invest in task decomposition, credit assignment, and verifiability (traces, proofs, checks).  
- The **compute posture** (AWS + existing partners) implies continued scale-ups; design for *multi-cloud portability* and *energy-aware* workloads to avoid concentration risk. citeturn3view0

**For enterprises**
- If the “light-touch” lane holds, the next 12–24 months favor **broad rollout**: coders (Codex-style), knowledge work with “company knowledge,” and production voice/vision agents. The 1M-customer stat suggests mainstreaming—budget and governance should follow. citeturn4view0

**For policy**
- Start **Lane-B scaffolding now**: interagency safety institutes; standardized control evals; biothreat guardrails; cross-border incident response. Don’t wait for the first major incident to define thresholds. citeturn1view0

---

## What to watch next (concrete)
- **Control evaluations:** any published test suite or third-party regime for “AI control” (the announcement points to this but lacks specs). citeturn1view0  
- **Foundation grants/roadmaps** on AI resilience (who gets funded, what tools/standards they push). citeturn2view0  
- **Supply deals** beyond AWS (capacity, timelines, energy sources), and whether cost/perf improvements keep pace with the 40× narrative. citeturn3view0  
- **Agentic product releases** tied to longer-horizon tasks (days→weeks), and whether evals show reliability gains, not just demos. citeturn4view0

---

## My take
- This is **more than PR**: it triangulates OpenAI’s technical direction (discovery-grade agents), operating constraints (compute), and governance ask (two lanes + resilience).  
- The **big bet** is that economics (falling unit costs) will outpace new risks. If the cost curve stalls—even temporarily—policy, safety, and business adoption timelines change materially.  
- The **open questions**—trigger thresholds for Lane B, specifics of control evals, and independent verification—will determine whether this plan scales without downstream shocks.

If you want, I can sketch an eval/verification stack for “discovery-grade” math/ML agents (benchmarks, proof-obligation structure, and traceable tool-use) that would be credible under the control-evaluation framing above.
